title: 114_s3473
content: The "Death Gratuity Equity Act of 2016" increases the death gratuity for federal civilian employees killed in the line of duty. The "Death Gratuity Equity Act of 2016" amends Title 5 of the United States Code to provide death gratuities for federal civilian employees who die in the line of duty. It defines terms like 'child' and 'civilian employee' and authorizes the payment of death gratuities. The Death Gratuity Equity Act of 2016 amends Title 5 to provide death gratuities for federal civilian employees who die in the line of duty. The head of an agency must pay a death gratuity from agency funds for a civilian employee's death resulting from duty-related injury, excluding natural causes or serious misconduct. The Death Gratuity Equity Act of 2016 amends Title 5 to provide death gratuities for federal civilian employees who die in the line of duty. The amount of a death gratuity paid under this section shall be $100,000 per civilian employee, adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The Death Gratuity Equity Act of 2016 provides death gratuities for federal civilian employees who die in the line of duty. The amount of a death gratuity paid under this section is determined by regulations and is $100,000 per civilian employee, adjusted annually. Payment is made to eligible survivors in a specified order of precedence. The order of payment for death gratuities to federal civilian employees is established in a specific order of precedence. A beneficiary designated by the employee in a signed and witnessed writing before their death takes precedence, while a will or other document not meeting these requirements has no effect. The order of payment for death gratuities to federal civilian employees is established in a specific order of precedence. If no beneficiary is designated, the payment goes to the surviving spouse, then to the child or children, followed by the surviving parent or parents, and finally to the executor or administrator of the estate if none of the previous options apply. Section 413 of the Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to change the terminology from "dependents" to "beneficiary" and to specify conditions for death gratuity payments to surviving beneficiaries of employees who die while on duty abroad. The amendment to section 413 of the Foreign Service Act of 1980 specifies conditions for death gratuity payments to surviving beneficiaries of employees who die while on duty abroad, including eligibility criteria and offset provisions for deaths occurring after a certain date. Additionally, payments under this section will not be considered gross income for the surviving beneficiary. SEC. 7. Emergency supplemental authorization in case an agency cannot meet the requirements of this act. Emergency supplemental authorization allows additional appropriations for agencies unable to meet the requirements of the Act due to natural disasters, terrorism, or other incidents. This includes extra payments under specified sections that exceed the agency's available funds. Additional payments authorized under subsection (a) require additional appropriations. Congress should vote on requests for additional appropriations within 30 days of submission.
